Full logs would be useful to have any look. Most importantly what binds has configd given to proxyd and whats up with iptables. From the little log above the only thing that it can tell us is that the 443 is not reachable which in turn, as it is in the same appliance (edit: spad connects to another appliance not the same. See last comment..), feels that the appliance setup of the role is broken. configd needs to open this port and start a proxyd there. Really smells appliance fuckery. However it is very strange unless someone touched configd or this scenario was never tested. Putting in in more info requires as needs some investigation to see if it is bug in configd or something else
My test env is still up there if you want to check it

Easy to reproduce, just create an env, disable logserver on controller, take a gateway, and enable only the logserver role on it.

Alright I did some investigation. Created an envy environment with 2 Gateways and 1 Controller. I disabled log server from Controller and enabled it in Gateway 2. Disabled Gateway role in Gateway 2 as well so the appliance functions only as a log server. The problem is as expected that proxyd is not running in the log server appliance! Thus all connections from Controller and Gateway 1 to the log server (ex Gateway 2) are failing as there is no proxyd listening at 443... The fix should be configd to start proxyd normally as usual (minus the client spa key. It's not needed)

\# Controller

\- Added an Express Connector validation for checking overlaps.

\- Fixed an issue where saving an LDAP Certificate Identity Provider with a CA certificate that does not have any Key Usage extension will fail with an error.

\- Fixed an issue where upgrade fails due to stale App Shortcuts in the database. This could be caused creating an Entitlement with App Shortcut on 5.0 and deleting it.

\- Fixed an issue where the privilege for testing name resolution for specific appliances cause errors. The privilege now cannot be assigned to specific Appliances but it requires View privilege as extra.

\- Fixed stats/failed-authentication API.

\# Frontend

\- Fixed an issue where the query, page and sorting order are reset after applying bulk actions.

\- Fixed an issue on Session Details where Express Connector only shows single gateway. Unlike the regular Clients, Express Connector connects to all the gateways on a Site.

\- Removed the unsupported "None" Access Method under Appliance - LogForwarder - AWS Kinesis.
Fix of issue with alert not working on http based actions.
Fix of a bug where name is included in pre expire remedies
Fix of a issue where the gateway complained about had access when SNAT mode was enabled
Fix of a issue that multiple entitlements was presented in sessions details on express-connectors
Improved filter setup time for large rule set in the firewall engine
Show name resolver creation errors in appliance status as part of gateway role.
access audit logs now contains identifier and sequence no.
In case of identical http and tcp actions, http actions now have preceding.
Small description update of ip-access audit log for blocking TCP segments without connection state
Fix of a bug where changing of filters on kinesis and tcp outputs did not result in changes beeing applied.
While there were a few small fixes on the appliance side, not much release note worthy.

# Appliance
- Fix bug in autoscaling script when dealing with appliance template with older version than the controller version.

Multiple http access urls with or without / postfixes may have nondeterministic behaviour on what url will be preferred

This is because the upgrade script only considers the site and not the roles too, gateways should be grouped separately:

def appliance_group_id(appliance: Appliance) -> str:
    """
    Return a group id used to group appliances logically, e.g. all gateways
    belonging to the same site. Use hashlib instead of the built-in hash
    to make the output stable across runs.
    """
    import hashlib
    m = hashlib.md5()
    if appliance.site:
        m.update(appliance.site.encode('utf-8'))
    if appliance.log_forwarder_sites:
        # We want a single log forwarder site to result in a different
        # group id than a single gateway site so they get grouped separately.
        m.update(str(appliance.log_forwarder_sites).encode('utf-8'))
    group_id = m.hexdigest()
    return group_id

In the SSO Client installation section in the Admin Guide(
it mentions several times that the switch /L should be always used when trying to install SSO client, nevertheles the example installation command line provided doesn't include it!.

I realize later that /SSO and /L are the same switch for the installer but it is a bit confusing, so maybe it will use /L in the example installation line or refer to this option as /SSO instead of /L.
The section I refer is below:

To install the client as a SSO service the installation needs to be run with the switch /L. It is recommended to run it using the /S (silent installation) switch. Refer to Windows Client for a full explanation of all the installation switch options. So run the following command from a command prompt to install the Windows SSO (PLAP) Client using silent mode and wait until installer is finished:

start "" /WAIT "AppGate Client Installer.exe" /SSO /S /G /U="

NOTE: The profile link included after the /U switch can be obtained from Settings>Client Connections.

An existing AppGate SDP installation can be upgraded to run as Windows SSO Client by simply running installer with /SSO and additional parameters (e.g. /U). The Client will be upgraded and the Windows SSO Client installed. Any existing configuration set for the normal Client will not be transferred to the SSO sign-in screen.

NOTE: Always provide the /L flag every time the AppGate SDP client is installed, upgraded or reinstalled to keep the AppGate SDP SSO functionality installed.

Because it looks for nameID and fails..
Try to parse (for a few versions) the nameID
If it succeeds, the flow is the same as before.
If it fails, then you send the token without any cookie.
If on-boarding MFA is disabled, Controller will return 200 with username+cookie. Store it.
If on-boarding MFA is enabled, Controller will returned 412 (I think) with username (5.2 Controller).
If the username is not there, you can give up or just do the MFA anyway. It will be MFA every login in that case.
Take the username and check if you have the cookie already in the SecureStorage
If you don't have the cookie, go the MFA step.
If you have it, try logging in with the cookie and the SAML token
Controller may still return 412 after this if the cookie is wrong. Then go to MFA step.
Otherwise Controller will return 200 with username+cookie. Store it.

The only tricky thing in the SDP config is that we need to assign the static IP as well as the DHCP with the matching IP address. This is so the controller can send the other connector's IP to each connector in the HA pair.

Notes about how to configure this feature:
IAM Role in the connector EC2 instances
The connector EC2  instances need to have assigned an IAM Role with the following actions:
with access to the ENIs attached to the connector instance (the ones that are involved in the Connector HA).
Security group for the connector EC2 instances
Each ec2 instance should allow access to protocol 112 from each other.
We need to assign an static private ip to the ENI for each EC2 connector instance. This is a workaround to limitations in the SDP (we need to know the IP in the nic to enable HA in connectors)
In the VPC subnet where our EC2 connectors are located we need to add a CIDR reservation for the VIP (so it will never be assigned to any machine in that subnet)
To workaround the limitation in SDP  we need to assign an static ip in the connectors configuration (The one we assigned to the ENI before) and DHCP at the same time.
I will endeavour to document this and ping you when it is done for checking.

After looking at this for quite a while, I couldn't shake the feeling that this is a very wrong approach. I understand the reason for wanting it and why it feels like there should be an option to change the admin password from cz-setup since you can set it there. But the admin password is global for the whole collective, cz-setup is only about channging the appliance where it is running. If there should be a way to change the admin password from the cli, it should be in cz-config.
There can be multiple admin users, the default admin user can easily get removed. There are a number of cases that should be considered.
cz-setup after seeding is basically a fancy gui to cz-config so tht isn't the major issue, but deciding precisely what this is supposed to do is.
Well, the task originally was to be able to change the password for the hardcoded user admin, from the cli.
But now Jamie also says it is wrong that cz-setup can change the password for the cz user...
-scott could you explain a bit more about this?
UPDATE: that's not wrong after all. In fact, there's nothing wrong with cz-setup and maybe cz-setup does not need to be involved at all.
The task is to add a CLI way to reset the admin password.
Yes, this is only for the user called "admin", if it exists
the default admin user can easily get removed.
Indeed. If no user named "admin" is found, we'll print an error message.
And i suppose the command is only supposed to work on controllers?
Yes. There needs to be some check for this.

Maybe we should also have a check that the cz user has a password or pk set? Right now cz is logged in automatically on the local and serial consoles and cloud providers have started handing out access to the serial console.
it is logged in automatically if the password is not set, after seeding+reboot even on serial it will ask for password. On cloud providers i suppose it all works differently.
Yes, on cloud providers the password is not set and there is no requirement for password on sudo either.

About the URL Access issue, I don't know if I agree with the temporary file fix.
Is the temporary file just a buffer for chunks of data, if so why not use memory?
Is it buffering the entire file? If so that will suck with big file uploads (e.g. >1GB) or even stuff like video streams.
Shouldn't we configure nginx to do real streaming of the uploaded and downloaded data instead? We are supposed to be as transparent as possible here.

It should at least refuse to run in that case... Or allow using the peer hostname.

A possible fix for this, the disambiguation flag should not be --admin-hostname but --peer-hostname since that one is guaranteed to be unique I you use a shared admin hostname the script will force you to pass --peer-hostname.
This workaround worked: 1. Disable admin interface on all but first controller 2. Run upgrade script with \
3. Enable admin interface again on all controllers

: The upgrade script just picks 1 controller matching the hostname used to connect to the admin API and sticks to it. Basically decoupling the connectiong hostname from the master controller selection.

CONTROLLER            AppGate SDP controller peer or admin hostname or ip
                        The server should be specified in the following form:
                            [

The hostname should point to a specific controller.
                        If the port is specified here it takes precedence over the port argument.
                        The port should be the AppGate SDP admin API port.
                        If the admin interface is configured, use admin interface port.
                        Else, use the peer interface port.
The --admin-hostname flag has been renamed to --unique-hostname:

--unique-hostname UNIQUE_HOSTNAME
                        Specify the unique hostname of the AppGate SDP controller you are connecting to.
                        Use this if connecting via an ip or hostname that differs from the peer or admin hostname or if the admin hostname is shared across multiple controllers

So the backup script can differentiate a controller DB down case from what is really a configuration problem and show a nice message to the admin.

Create controller and gateway as separated appliances. 4.0.4 was used in this example.
Turn off the controller and try to upgrade the gateway to 4.1.0.
The expected result is that it should fail, since it cannot verify that the controller already is upgraded.
But at attempt 10, the gateway suddenly assumes the "force" flag was used.
And thus the upgrade is done after all.

- not very clear what we need to docuent here.

When we redirect the client to SAML destinations, some of the SAML providers require some extra parameters in the URL, namely "SAMLRequest=<base64>". That includes some details that the provider validates. Google SAML and Azure ADFS requires it, so it's good for that. Others ignore it unless you configure them to require.

The only thing I have noticed is it happens when you have a looot of logs.
I'm lowering the prio to 300 as this isn't really a blocker, but we still need to look into it as it's annoying, it gets in the way of getting logs from customers when they have other issues.

I managed to reproduce it, by using this python script
It does not seem to be related to configd, since curl terminates first, and then after a few seconds configd reports that the connection is closed and makes an exception.
Because the code is compressing files one by one and then sending them, while they are getting compressed no data is sent. If no data is sent for 30 seconds, the connection gets dropped.
The client (at least curl) has no timeouts it seems. I tried connecting it to nc on localhost. It just sends the request and hangs, so it is the server which is closing the connection.
OK, so there is hope that we can fix this without changing the file format then.
Also got to change the journald thing from using tempfiles to streaming, otherwise I get the timeout there too.

The logConsentrator will be a new role in the appgateSDP. With HA support, So you will be able to have multiple logConsentrators and the other appliances will be able to send their ogs to the consentrator.
The logConsentrator will be able to send logs over tcp/relp or elasticsearch destination.
If one logConsentrator is down, other appliances will connect to another logConsentrator and continue operation.
example logd configuration on a logConsentrator (same as for the logserver, but the elasticSearchUrl is different, and may have multiple other destinations)

geoIpDbPath: /etc/cz-geoip/GeoLite2-City.mmdb

logLevel: INFO

logServer: true

mappingFile: /etc/cz-elasticsearch/mapping.json

persistanceMode: default

relpClients:

  - format: syslog

    host: 127.0.0.1

    name: rsyslog

    port: 20514

tcpClients:

  - format: json

    host: 192.168.111.162

    name: extLog

    port: 12345

relpServer:

  bindHost: 127.0.0.1

  bindPort: 9320
This one is sending logs to elasticsearch/local relp/external tcp
example ffwd configuration on a logConsentrator: (same as for a logserver)

server:

  allowedDestinations:

    TCP/9301: \[\]

    TCP/9320: \[\]

    TCP/9350: \[\]

  disabledDnChecks:

    - TCP/9320

  listenPath: /run/cz-ffwd/ffwd.socket

  listenPathGroup: cz-ffwd

  listenPathOwner: czd-priv

You can see this is a replacement for the rsyslog solution. If you have a external log-system, using a logAggregator will be a much more convenient way to setup the logging system. A logAggregator you can configure for ONE or SEVERAL sites. And then the appliances will use that as their logging destination. Much in the same way, as if it was a logserver.
The logAggregator can be then configured to have log destination and support:
TCP (syslog or json format) and plain text or TLS.
Elasticsearch (plain, or using AWS role, or AWS credentials)
Since its using websockets, you also when configuring ports, only need to allow 444 between the appliances and the logAggregator.
It also solves a special problem that
had, were in appgate as a service, you want to send the logs within the appgate system..
Its hard a clumbersum to setup a solution (with rsyslog) when in appgate as a service you have gateways on customersite but want to collect the logs of these
Also, i think for appgate insight this will be a much more workable solution compare to the rsyslog alternative

in AppGate as a service (== hosted controllers), where we do not offer a hosted logging, we want to be able to deliver (safe and guaranteed) all logs into the customers log-sink (SIEM, log etc.) This can be achieved with a a log-aggregator which can is positioned in customer's environment, collects the the controller's logs and forwards them to the customer's log-sink, as a in-band traffic.

If we need to provide hosted logging, we can extend the portfolio: We could offer (==charge for) a hosted logging service with all the fancy features, and it could just scale up as much as we like. This could be a tierd system where frontend, backend and storage is separated (tenant and architecture wise). The logstream (namespace) however needs to plugin, hence we can have log-aggregators as the connector to customer's AppGate (in our environment), and this does not necessary has to be Agaas customers. There might be many more features and services added upon this, such as analytics (brainspace)etc...(basically anything that can be leveraged from logs).
So logAggregator will be a new role in 4.3. The purpose of a logAggregator is to collect logs from other appliances and forwards them to 1 or several destinations.

So, the following is what I gathered so far.

When you specify a Log Aggregator you are required to chose one or many sites to which the aggregator applies. By doing so that aggregator will become the default logging service for any appliance belonging to that site. So if setting up an aggregator in AWS and connecting it to the AWS site all appliances in AWS will log its data locally to that aggregator.

A Log Aggregator can use Elasticsearch, TCP clients or Relp clients to connect to an external log server. The configuration for these alternatives are given when a user choses to add one or many in their respective lists. Note that at the moment only one Elasticsearch entry can be made, so that list can only contain one entry for now. It's being implemented as a list from the start for consistency.

There can be only one LogServer OR one/many Log Aggregators in the same system. The UI logic for this is handled at the point of saving the form so it will not be possible to add a Log Aggregator when there is already a LogServer present.
Can you apply multiple sites to one LogAggregator?
Can you have a system with one LogServer and multiple LogAggregators (on different appliances)? Or is it one or the other?
Can you apply multiple sites to one LogAggregator? > YES
Can you have a system with one LogServer and multiple LogAggregators > NO. You eigher have logserver or logAggregators
Can you apply multiple sites to one LogAggregator? > YES

So.. I talked with jim.anthony, and he was having problems with the tilemaps in kibana. The maps are downloaded by kibana when you are showing a map.
By default right now is that kibana uses a free service elastic is using.. But its possible to use others.
The default one was not downloading for jim fast enough. so what he did was to register for another service. and then change the configuration in kibana /etc/cz-kibana/config.yaml
So.. it would be good to be able to set the custom tilemap through the logserver configuration in the UI.

Since we now adays are unable to use maps in kibana,.. then i guess this is not going to happen

Alright so the url access module now has its structures to be able to do the filtering so the piece remaining is to add connectivity with sessiond to get those data
Thought it would end today as we already have all the IPC code in a library which gateway daemons use to talk to sessiond BUT nginx had a surprise...

You cannot have a thread or whatever running "on the side" doing its business. The module is just functions that you can hook in the asych cycle of nginx. You can create stuff "on the side" but they will vanish as nginx is spawning/destroying worker processes and other magic stuff. The nginx\
thread idea is just to offload tasks (called from the hooks of the cycle) in case that is needed
Sooo the best way from the ways PoCed so far is to work with nginx not against it... Follow its model.
sessiond can send the json data in simple POST call! nginx is already a dude that you can send data to it so the side channel was actually a really bad idea anyways
Works really nice (so far in the PoC) as you can hook properly to the cycle read the POST and do whatever you want with the data
\[emerg\] 8819#8819: \*1 sessiond send us a POST, client: 127.0.0.1, server: , request: "POST /data HTTP/1.1", host: "localhost:1234"
Writing down a problem: Nginx is multi process in case you set it with

this means that when sessiond does a POST only the filter of that processes will get updated leaving other worker processes with stale filter. Nginx uses shared memory for the worker processes to share data between them but that it is not something dynamic. Moreover the HashTables are Glib and they use the heap. We would need to implement HashTable wih nginx memory management so it can be shaved in the shared memory segment and also take care for the expansian. Major PITA. Let's start with having 1 worker process to get the feature done.

This was useful when transitioning from the old jsonrpc code to the state machine, it's now just an overcomplex additional layer.
I'm thinking about how to do this once we switch to themachine since it doesn't provide a built-in RPC.

Also we want to move the request id away from the event objects since they should be pure data related to the event. The extra Json layer is also superfluous since it's all in memory so we can build an RPC layer dealing with python objects directly.
If we want to keep a clean separation between the state machine layer and the "RPC" layer.
The RPC layer will be exposed only via the rest API, since seeding can be done just by reading the current state and pushing seed events.
One option is defining a Request class instead of directly using events.
The request event would contain a request id, a reference to the response queue and an event.
We probably don't even need to expose them
So for example if you want to do start an upgrade, imaging an simple upgrade event:
you would instantiate a request on top of it:
# automatically assigns a request id and a response queue
The request helper would automatically set the response queue and return a Request object.
The RPC layer would then consume incoming requests one by one, unpack the events and feed them to the state machine.
Now I'm still missing the piece where you send a response from the state machine...
Another option here is to ditch RPC in general and go full async.
That is make all write operations async with a way to query the status later.
Read operations can use the state and status views and return directly.
This would actually match for the following things:
pushing config -> The controller already treats that as async
upgrading -> We have an async API in the form of do API call + check upgrade status. The upgrade script works like that already
backup -> We have an async API already
So let's say we dump the whole synchronous request/response thing.
Then we make all APIs do basic validations and fire an event. There should then be a way to query for the status of that particular operation.

More specifically, the required hotfix is this one:
Installer needs to be updated with KB requirements/checks. Which will be very hairy and require lots of testing and pain.
We want to capture the hostnames user tries to access but fails due to lack of entitlement, and present them in Controller UI as a list.
In order to limit number of hostnames to manageable size, we'll let administrators to configure App Discovery Domains in the Site form such as \
For all the configured dns servers under Identity Providers, vpnd will listen all dns queries that are under \
.devops.ad.cryptzone.com and collect them IF they are dropped (with no matching IPs in rules)

Controller UI will have an Discovered Apps page, possibly linked from the Site, that queries all Gateways under that site and lists all discovered domains.  As a bonus, we may have a button to create entitlement directly from that page.
Would be nice to threat this in a similar way as some of the stats. Group the dns names by most common ones. Like top 20 or so (or maybe all) and keep track of the number of hits for each
There will always be mis-types so might be good to drop the 1s totally.
Typos will only be included if they actually resolve to an ip.

We need to parse DNS responses not queries. A DNS response verifies first of all that the host name requested is valid so we don't spend time and resources on crap. Moreover we get the IP(s) of that host name! Hence an entitlement can be created with using either the host name or the IP(s)

You need at least an entitlement with an Action that allows access to a DNS server
cz-vpnd is configured by cz-configd through Admin UI (Site settings) with some pre-configured domains
When cz-vpnd sees a DNS response as return traffic (i.e. a DNS request has been sent) it parses the packet and extracts hostnames-IPs
The IPs are checked against the tompf binary radix tree and if the IP exists the entry is dropped as it means we already have some IP rule for it
The hostname is checked against a cache, that works as statistics as well, to see if we have already discovered this app. If it is already seen entry is dropped
If we haven't seen it and no IP rule in the tree then vpnd's user-session inform cz-sessiond for the new entry
cz-sessiond accumulates all these entries and fine tunes his "report". Throws away any duplicate reports (as many sessions can find same App etc etc)
sessiond can be queried with a GET to return this report
When you say throw away dupes......are we counting the number of users requesting a discovered app? So we end up with our top 10 most requests?
And the word cloud shows just the word
And my app.here.cryptzone.com would only be shown in case 1 and 2.
And youtrack.cryptzone.com would only be shown in case 1 and 2.

Since that would create confusion, we added a validation to the controller so that it won't allow conflicting domain names like that. I think you were in the discussion even when we decided to do that.

just checking the eventual outcome (yes I followed the discussion) - so the Controller filters - and will only show one result for youtrack in the above case. But would show it twice (different colours) if it discovered youtrack.cyxtera and youtrack.cryptzone.
you can't have the above case.
as the app discovery list, controller will say no..
But would show it twice (different colours) if it discovered youtrack.cyxtera and youtrack.cryptzone.

I'll make an improvement on configd so if it's a controller itself, it will directly go to the internal controller service, but this still needs some improvement as nginx not starting is bad.
failed. explanation at the last PR
In that case the configuration contains the hostname of the controller.
If nginx is started before DHCP has applied the DNS configuration nginx startup will fail.
The fix for this should be the same as for
We should wait for the DHCP lease before leaving apply network configuration.
This way everything should be in place when we apply the services configuration.

While I have seen nginx failing to start on AWS it eventually resolves itself as configd does several restart during init on cloud platforms. Since cloud platforms are the only ones where we would deploy a standalone log server using DHCP we can consider this an acceptable known issue for 4.1 and fix it properly for 4.2.
Fixed by waiting for the DHCP configuration to be applied before continuing

Seems to happen when you bash the OK button :D
Ok it becaause the controller is doing several changes in a row.
The source of the problem is that you can click the OK button many times and it will send as many queries to the controller.
Logs coming from the Azure Gateway to the log server hosted at Connect (log.sa.cryptzone.com) time out from now and then.

Notes about the bonus fixed here which is getting upstart's logs itself in syslog

apparently Upstart (1.5) does not log to syslog, that is, it doesn't call the glibc function syslog(). Instead, Upstart logs to the kernel ring buffer, which is what dmesg reads. Now, I didn't think it was possible for user space processes to write to that buffer, but apparently they can by writing to /dev/kmsg, and that's exactly what Upstart does. So that's the first part of the puzzle.

The second part is that there's a widely-held belief that messages written to the kernel ring buffer are automatically copied to syslog by the kernel (at least that's what I always thought). Turns out this is actually done by a user space daemon, traditionally klogd, which operates in tandem with syslogd. Obviously rsyslogd replaces syslogd but apparently it replaces klogd as well (sort of: see notes at the end).

The third part is that messages written to the kernel ring buffer from user space actually look different from messages written from kernel space: they have a different facility. dmesg has a few options that interact with this: -x will show the facility (and the priority), while -u and -k tell dmesg to show only user facility messages and kernel facility messages, respectively.

Now here's the clincher: by default, rsyslogd ignores messages with a non-kernel facility when it's reading messages from the kernel ring buffer. The relevant config option is $KLogPermitNonKernelFacility, which is off by default and needs to be turned on if you want rsyslogd to process these messages. Note that the rest of rsyslogd's config will treat all messages from the kernel ring buffer as having the kern facility, irrespective of the facility they had in the kernel ring buffer.

When configd starts and finds that it has no config, it will check if /mnt/boot/metadata/is-aws exists, and if it does, it will enable DHCP on eth0 (either manually or by seeding itself), then it will download

Here is a copy/paste list of what the
The Azure Linux Agent (/usr/sbin/waagent) manages interaction between a virtual machine and the Azure Fabric Controller. It does the following:
Deploy SSH public keys and key pairs
Publishes the host name to the platform DNS
Reports SSH host key fingerprint to the platform
Formats and mounts the resource disk
Manages routes to improve compatibility with platform DHCP servers
Ensures the stability of the network interface name
Configures SCSI timeouts for the root device (which could be remote)
Redirects the console to the serial port
Detects and bootstraps the VMM agent for Linux when running in a System Center Virtual Machine Manager 2012 R2 environment
Inject component authored by Microsoft and Partners into Linux VM (IaaS) to enable software and configuration automation
The information flow from the platform to the agent occurs via two channels:
A boot-time attached DVD for IaaS deployments. This DVD includes an OVF-compliant configuration file that includes all provisioning information other than the actual SSH keypairs.
A TCP endpoint exposing a REST API used to obtain deployment and topology configuration.

Azure recently made a lot of changes, one of them is that the "Azure Resource Manager (arm)" stack is now the default.
I set out to test if we now can do most of the work from the web portal interface, but quickly found out the portal interface is way too limited.
So I installed the Azure CLI to get the work done. Azure Powershell has not been needed so far.
From the portal interface I launched a standard ubuntu 14.04 VM, uploaded the installation files and added a new disk.

sudo apt-get install lvm2 unzip

sudo ./cz-install --partition --boot-device /dev/sda --device /dev/sdc --archive appgate-xdp-1.0.1.1461-master.img.zip
The installation took well over 40 minutes. I used a Standard\
A1 machine which is quite weak.
I did not add the initial seed at this stage. I did it later, like this

sudo mount /dev/czvg/image1 /media

./cz-seed --dhcp-ipv4 eth0 --hostname acapulco --password cz secretpassword > /media/home/cz/seed.json
Now to add that disk to a new VM. This cannot be done from the portal as there is no way to create an "empty" vm
from there and Azure treats OS disks as a special case, they cannot be detached or replaced.
I created it with these command

azure network public-ip create Group-1 testip1 northeurope

azure network nic set --network-security-group-name ubuntu-kasper Group-1 kasper-nic1

azure vm create --verbose --vm-size Standard\_A1 --resource-group Group-1 --name kasper-try1 --location northeurope --os-type Linux --nic-name kasper-nic1 --os-disk-vhd [
And that's all there is to get it running!

Sentinel capabilities at a macroscopical level (i.e. the big picture)
Monitoring. Sentinel constantly checks if your master and slave instances are working as expected.
Notification. Sentinel can notify the system administrator, another computer programs, via an API, that something is wrong with one of the monitored Redis instances.

Automatic failover. If a master is not working as expected, Sentinel can start a failover process where a slave is promoted to master, the other additional slaves are reconfigured to use the new master, and the applications using the Redis server informed about the new address to use when connecting.

Configuration provider. Sentinel acts as a source of authority for clients service discovery: clients connect to Sentinels in order to ask for the address of the current Redis master responsible for a given service. If a failover occurs, Sentinels will report the new address.
Redis Sentinel is a distributed system

Sentinel itself is designed to run in a configuration where there are multiple Sentinel processes cooperating together. The advantage of having multiple Sentinel processes cooperating are the following:
Failure detection is performed when multiple Sentinels agree about the fact a given master is no longer available. This lowers the probability of false positives.

Sentinel works even if not all the Sentinel processes are working, making the system robust against failures. There is no fun in having a fail over system which is itself a single point of failure, after all.
Fundamental things to know about Sentinel before to deploy
You need at least three Sentinel instances for a robust deployment.

The three Sentinel instances should be placed into computers or virtual machines that are believed to fail in an independent way. So for example different physical servers or Virtual Machines executed on different availability zones.

Sentinel + Redis distributed system does not guarantee that acknowledged writes are retained during failures, since Redis uses asynchronous replication. However there are ways to deploy Sentinel that make the window to lose writes limited to certain moments, while there are other less secure ways to deploy it.
Masters are called M1, M2, M3, ..., Mn.
Slaves are called R1, R2, R3, ..., Rn (R stands for replica).
Sentinels are called S1, S2, S3, ..., Sn.

This is a very simple setup, that has the advantage to be simple to tune for additional safety. It is based on three boxes, each box running both a Redis process and a Sentinel process. If the master M1 fails, S2 and S3 will agree about the failure and will be able to authorize a failover, making clients able to continue.

Note: In every Sentinel setup, being Redis asynchronously replicated, there is always the risk of losing some write because a given acknowledged write may not be able to reach the slave which is promoted to master

We make the master sentinel process to hang deliberately for some seconds:

All sentinel processes find out that the master redis process has hung and immediately they vote to elect a new leader! The new master becomes the redis process that lives on 192.168.111.50. We can see the realization of the hang, voting and election in the sentinel logs and we can verify it with the cli:
It should be noted that when the node with the redis process returns from the deliberate hang, it changes role to a slave as there is already a new boss in the hood! (can be seen in the logs as well)

Obsolete since the whole thing has changed.
This task is to group some improvements in the UI and configuration of XDP to make it easier for customers to onboard a new installation.
When creating a new identity provider we should add following items:
\- create automatically a new filter call "All users for <name identity provider>
\- create an entitlement called DNS that allows DNS port 53 (DNS IP's provided by identity provider) with filter All Users for <name identity provider>
Fill in the same DNS as the controller appliance (customers can overrule)
Create a default filter called Everyone
Fill in client and peer hostname with hostname of appliance and allow customers to overwrite
If GW is selected we should check if we find the NIC's with private IP ranges and add that interface to allowed sources. If only 1 NIC is used, add that NIC to allow sources by default
the log file filter Field in Controller should be much bigger
Automatically revoke (spread over 5-10 min) Entitlements when one of them is updated
Auto refresh Dashboard after X time
When scrolling right page, the left menu shouldn't scroll with it
Basic server templates that you can assign in actions (like ICMP + Port 80/443)
Auto refresh Dashboard after X time
this should be working like that already; every 15 minutes though.

The goal of this task is to get familiar with what single packet authorization is and play with software using it (e.g.
) in preparation of implementing SPA on the gateway and tun-service.

SPA message = UID, CTR, OTP, GMAC

Seed = Shared secret for OTP

UID  = Universal ID of the client - We can use the DN which the client produces

CTR  = A counter which  is hashed with seed to create OTP

OTP  = One time password created as HMAC(seed || CTR)

GMAC = signature of the first 3 for data authentication using \`E\` which is a key used for the GMAC AES 256 - we can use the ephemeral key that controller calculates for each client and it is used so far for signing the IP states
As we dont have yet a way of delivering the seed we can use as seed a hard-coded value
TOTP is based on HOTP with a timestamp replacing the incrementing counter.

The current timestamp is turned into an integer time-counter (TC) by defining the start of an epoch (T0) and counting in units of a time step (TS). For example:

TC = floor((unixtime(now)  unixtime(T0)) / TS),

TOTP = HOTP(SecretKey, TC),

TOTP-Value = TOTP mod 10d, where d is the desired number of digits of the one-time password.

Single Packet Authorization mandates a similar architecture to port knocking. Both have client and server components, the server maintains control of a default-drop packet filter, and the server monitors packets passively. However, this is where the architectural similarities between port knocking and SPA diverge.

Single Packet Authorization moves the data transmission to where it belongsin the application layer. This implies that instead of being able to send only two bytes of data per packet, as in the case of port knocking, SPA is able to send up to the minimum MTU worth of data (1,500 bytes on Ethernet networks) between the client and the server in each packet.
fwknop defines the following packet format at the application layer:

16 bytes of random data

Client username

Client timestamp

fwknop version

Mode (access or command)

Access (or command string)

MD5 sum

Many of the fields in the SPA packet format have a variable length, but are separated by a : character (fields are base64-encoded, so embedded colons cannot break this syntax). Once the fwknop client builds the packet format above, the entire packet is encrypted using one of two encryption algorithms: the Rijndael symmetric block cipher with a 128-bit shared key or the asymmetric ElGamal algorithm with up to a 2,048-bit public/private key pair generated by GnuPG. By default, the fwknop client sends SPA packets over UDP port 62201, but this easily can be changed from the command line;

added nameid by adding a claim mapping of SAM-Account-Name to NameID
Create a script that prepares emulators etc:
Collect the apk and load it on the emulator
Start the app and wait 60 secs and collect any exception messages
This is just to see that generated apk actually loads all assemblies and starts. Sometimes we break assembly loading so this should help with that.
Adding automated test cases that runs on an Android emulator can follow this task.
Emulator startup times are fluctuating a lot so predefined wait time even on my machine is failing half the time. Found a script to check emulator readiness in a loop though so will try that:

\# Emulator Management: Create, Start and Wait

before\_script:

  - echo no | android create avd --force -n test -t android-21 --abi armeabi-v7a

  - emulator -avd test -no-skin -no-audio -no-window &

  - curl [

> android-wait-for-emulator

  - chmod u+x android-wait-for-emulator

  - ./android-wait-for-emulator

  - adb shell input keyevent 82 &

yes, OKTA and ADFS has the support.

Awesome. You have encrypted assertions and encrypted attributes. Sigh.
Encrypted attributes doesn't seem to be common, as I couldn't find any example at all. Will implement encrypted assertion only
surprise, surprise; can't use the same code for both. Investigating
The scenario is : 1 controller, 2 gateways on the same site, and 1 endpoint behind the gateways.
does a ssh connection to gw1 and gw2 , and starts up had, and configures vpnd for ha.
it enables telnet port 23 and ssh port 2222 on the endpoint through entitlements.A connection is made towards gw1
A ssh connection is made towards endpoint, over port 2222, and a command "whoami" is executed to make sure that the connection is established.
The test then ssh into the gw1 and kills all of the vpnds.
and then issues a command over the ssh connection towards the endpoint to make sure that the connection is still alive.
The connection gets a reset, and the connection is lost.. (Connection reset by peer)
By doing tcpdumps on the test-runner machine and the gateway it can be seen that a RST packet is seen on the client machine:
This packet is never seen when doing tcpDump on the gw. so it seems like the packet is created on the client machine.

Envy is the new environment handler for the "toolchain".
Envy will need to be modular and well designed so we can support flexible scenarios with multiple VM vendors.
My idea is to rewrite the POC and make the service easily extendable, for instance if we need to support different tools than Terraform (which I hope won't be the case).
will be made up of few components.
The main envy process will spawn two subprocesses.
- Will handle incoming requests in jsonrpc format and dispatch them to a
- Will take care of managing which networks are available in our local environment (vmware). It won't care about cloud providers. (Or was this something
was going to take care of
will be supported as plugins. To start with we will only have one handler,
must be able to support all the available scenarios.
pretty flexible when it comes to scenarios. However, we can't design it in a way that makes it too complicated to handle. For instance,

shouldn't care about anything that already exists in AWS when spawning up an environment there. For example, we will not support spawning up the scenario into an already existing VPC. We will always start from scratch, by creating the VPC, etc., and then we clean up after ourselves.

will generate the Terraform formulas "on the fly" - meaning, it will programmatically generate formulas in json format, instead of the default Terraform format (Terraform supports json for formulas as well).
A suggested format for scenario definition. Each provider is very unique - but the API interface must be able to hide all the details.
For example, let's say we want to create a scenario that will be labelled
One appliance running controller and gateway.

Ommitted bool fields will default to false.Connection and auth details for various providers will be saved locally so there is no need for the client to provide that to the API. The only thing that is required is to provide the API with a jsonrpc formatted request, an test/environments specific uuid and the scenario that should be created. In case of cleaning up environments, it would be enough to provide the API with the same test/environments uuid as was given when the environments were created.
will also report in case of a failure and tell
will clean up in case of a failure.

The problem is that udev creates a mapping of nic names to mac addresses but we dont persist it so names CAN change at every reboot if there is no deterministic way to assign the nic names on that hardware.
Workaround, after first boot do this to persist mapping:
:/home/cz# nano /mnt/root-rw/etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules - Change so that pluged-in 10 gigabit network are labled eth0 and eth1 root
I can suggest a few different solutions:

We allow the option to specify a physical MAC address in the appliance config for each NIC, so that you can tie down the NIC names the way you want. Actually, if the assignment is random, even with a persistent file, the assignment on first boot might not match the numbering on the physical or virtual server!

Configd copies /etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules to /mnt/state/patches/xxx/etc/udev/rules.d/70-persistent-net.rules on startup. Will not persist across upgrades though, and will not pick up changes if NICs are added.
Extract the assignments and save in local.json on first boot, then compile the rules file from config. Will not pick up changes if NICs are added.
Fix Linux/Debian/Ubuntu, wherever this comes from? Is there really no notion of NIC order on the hardware level?
Some hints on how to change order at runtime:

We allow the option to specify a physical MAC address in the appliance config for each NIC, so that you can tie down the NIC names the way you want. Actually, if the assignment is random, even with a persistent file, the assignment on first boot might not match the numbering on the physical or virtual server!

I think that is what systemd does by default now so fixed in 16.04. They use interface names based on the mac address. The problem is that our whole configuration relies on names like eth0. We need to think if this is the right way to do it long term.
Fix Linux/Debian/Ubuntu, wherever this comes from? Is there really no notion of NIC order on the hardware level?
That mostly depends on driver support I think. So there are two fixes: switch to systemd like ubuntu did or upgrade the NIC drivers for the physical appliance we support.

Yes, that is the butt-ugly solution. It breaks the filesystem checksum. :-)
This paragraph caught my attention in the Systemd article:

This combined policy is only applied as last resort. That means, if the system has biosdevname installed, it will take precedence. If the user has added udev rules which change the name of the kernel devices these will take precedence too. Also, any distribution specific naming schemes generally take precedence.
Apparently Ubuntu (at least some flavors of it) come with biosdevname preinstalled. It's not included in Ubuntu Core, so we would have to include it ourselves. It looks promising:
I had it already installed on my virtual Ubuntu Server, but for some reason it was not being used by the system. Googling for it I found:
Further, [DELL1] states that new naming scheme kicks in if:
SMBIOS has a version >= 2.6 and SMBIOS Type 9 and Type 41 tables are supported.
If the first point does not hold, it falls back to the IRQ Routing Table
Well, it would be nice if the man page of biosdevname(1) or [DELL1] state a little more prominently, that
the new naming scheme is not used under any circumstances when running in a VM

Apparently this software is written by Dell, for use with PowerEdge servers and nothing else, and the Ubuntu guys are discussing whether to use biosdevname on physical servers but ethN on other machines, as this creates inconsistency:

And by the way, even if we forcibly enabled biosdevname on virtual machines, it seems the numbering becomes unpredictable, whereas it is now predictable. The command-line tool says that my VM's NICs would be called p2p1, p7p1 and p8p1. How would I know that in advance?
None of the solutions works all the time. In a virtual machine with 10 nics, the booting algorithm changes the PCI number all the time, it seems, so we need to match the name via the mac address.
Also, if you read the last link above, biosdevname can be quite buggy.

So in summary I think we should avoid using biosdevname, and instead use ethN or the systemd scheme, whatever the OS gives us, and at least for ethN we should allow selecting an interface by MAC address, as that seems to be the surest way.
Ok, we could avoid this problem by upgrading the drivers for the specific NICs we will use for hardware appliances. For virtual appliances this problem does not seem to appear anyways.
What difference would an updated driver make for the ordering?

I think the problem with undeterministic order only occurs if the driver doesn't have enough information to reliably order the NICs. We don't see it with most NICs we tried, only some particular (10Gbit) models.

Interesting. Have we confirmed that the problem goes away on our performance testing machines if we use newer drivers? Also, will we have control over the hardware the customers are going to use, or will we distribute the XDP installer ISO, meaning that the customers can install on any machine?

Well we have only seen it happen on the hardware we use for performance testing, not on the hardware we plan on selling (at least so far, lets see what Kasper finds). I think the idea is that we only support the hardware that we sell. ISO are to be used by customers only for deploying virtual machines.
Now I figured out why I never got the persistent-rules file in my VM's, it's because Ubuntu's script filters out VirtualBox NICs, so rules will not be autogenerated for these.

Also, I tried out Ubuntu Server 15.10 which has gone full systemd, and instead of eth0 I get enp0s3. This is another problem, since the NIC names need to be known in advance when creating a config to be exported. You can apparently configure systemd to use a different naming scheme.

I think we need to decide how we want to handle NIC ordering and naming schemes, preferably come up with a solution which suits both 14.04 and 16.04. My suggestion is to stay with the ethN scheme (even in 16.04), but to let the admin (optionally) specify each ethN by MAC address. (It's not entirely straightforward though. For instance, if the MAC is specified for one NIC, it should be specified for all NICs, otherwise we have a mess.)
